title: West Coast drugs culture ‘cost us a flag’
text:
Andrew Embley admits off-field culture may have cost West Coast Eagles ‘winning another flag’ March 21, 2017 4:22pm Source: FOX SPORTS NORM Smith medallist Andrew Embley has admitted that West Coast’s toxic off-field culture during the 2000s might have cost his former club another premiership. 
Embley’s revelation comes after a previously unreleased AFL report was published in the Herald Sun on Tuesday , exposing a decade of illicit drug use and other misdemeanours. 
The report, spearheaded by retired Victorian Supreme Court judge William Gillard, centres on one of the club’s most successful eras — from 2001 to 2007 when the Eagles made two Grand Finals and won a premiership in 2006 led by 2005 Brownlow Medallist Ben Cousins. 
Upon reading the report, Richmond legend Kevin Bartlett told SEN radio that he would put a “black line through that (2006) flag”. 
Embley, who won the Norm Smith medal in the 2006 grand final, described Bartlett’s comments as “strong”, but said that the flag shouldn’t be seen as tainted, as the players never took performance-enhancing substances. 
However Embley admitted the club’s off-field culture may have contributed to the club falling short in other years. 
“The one thing I will say is that whilst I don’t ever agree with taking illicit drugs, there’s a big difference between illicit drugs and performance-enhancing drugs,” Embley told TAB radio .

“I don’t think there’s an argument yet to tell me illicit drugs are performance-enhancing. That’s the big difference for mine. 
“If anything, it probably actually cost us winning another flag with what potentially went on. 
“That’s probably what I have to say there. I know our football club did a lot of work post that 2006 era to work on our culture and make sure we became a much better club. 
“I think for the work that the club did, that’s the reason why they’re in the position that they’re in at the moment.” 
In his Tuesday radio editorial, Bartlett slammed former Eagles coach — now Essendon coach — John Worsfold and West Coast chief executive Trevor Nisbett, saying “clearly judge Gillard felt they did not act strongly enough on compelling evidence”. Andrew Embley won the Norm Smith medal in 2006. Picture: Jody D’Arcy Source: News Limited 
But Embley said Bartlett’s statement was unfair. 
“Of course there were rumours and innuendo and I guess from a club perspective all they can do is sit in front of particular players and look them in the eye and ask for the honest truth. When people tell them something then it’s actually really hard to be able to act on stuff,” Embley said. 
“It was a difficult time for everyone and I know a lot of people were hurt through this. But all I can say is that from someone who was there throughout that time, I back our hierarchy in that they did everything they could with the evidence they had from the playing group.” 
Embley’s premiership teammate Sam Butler, who’s still on the Eagles’ list, said Bartlett’s comments were “painful”. 
“I think we trained harder and wanted it more than any other team that year and that’s how I feel about that year when I look back on it,” Butler told TAB radio . 
“We have got players’ lives that have been hurt by it, but 99 per cent of the boys in that team are now fully-fledged members of society and are great people and always have been great people.”
